MVDatasets
  • Camera
  • View page source

Camera

class mvdatasets.camera.Camera(intrinsics: ndarray, pose: ndarray, rgbs: ndarray | None = None, masks: ndarray | None = None, normals: ndarray | None = None, depths: ndarray | None = None, instance_masks: ndarray | None = None, semantic_masks: ndarray | None = None, global_transform: ndarray | None = None, local_transform: ndarray | None = None, timestamps: ndarray = array([0.]), camera_label: str = '0', width: int | None = None, height: int | None = None, near: float = 0.1, far: float = 10000.0, temporal_dim: int = 1, subsample_factor: int = 1, verbose: bool = False)

Camera class to manage intrinsics, pose, and various image data. As of now, all given data MUST have the same temporal and spatial dimensions.

distance_to_points_3d_world(points_3d_world: array | Tensor) → ndarray | Tensor

Computes the distance from the camera origin to 3D points in world space.

Parameters:

  • camera (Camera) – Camera object with a get_pose() method.

  • points_3d_world (np.ndarray or torch.Tensor) – 3D points in world space of shape (N, 3).

Returns:

Distances from the camera to the points, shape (N,).

Return type:

np.ndarray or torch.Tensor

Raises:

ValueError – If points_3d_world is of an unsupported type or shape.

get_available_data() → list

return all available data keys that are not None :returns: available data keys :rtype: list

get_camera_label() → int

return camera index

get_center() → ndarray

returns camera center in world space :returns: (3,) camera center :rtype: np.ndarray

get_data(points_2d_screen: Tensor | None = None, frame_idx: int = 0, keys: list | None = None, device: str = 'cpu', verbose: bool = False) → dict

return data values for points_2d_screen :returns: data values at points_2d_screen :rtype: vals (dict)

get_data_dict() → dict

return all camera data :returns: all camera data :rtype: dict

get_depth(frame_idx: int = 0) → ndarray

return, if exists, the depth map at frame_idx, else None :param frame_idx: frame index. Defaults to 0. :type frame_idx: int, optional

Returns:

(H, W, 1) depth frame

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_depths() → ndarray

return, if exists, all camera depth maps, else None :returns: (T, H, W, 1) depth frames :rtype: np.ndarray

get_height() → int

return camera image height

Returns:

get_intrinsics_inv() → ndarray

(H, W, 1) mask frame

(H, W, 3) normal frame

get_normals() → ndarray

get_opengl_matrix_world() → ndarray

return w2c matrix :returns: (4, 4) opengl matrix world :rtype: np.ndarray

get_opengl_projection_matrix() → ndarray

get_pixels(device: str = 'cpu') → Tensor

returns all pixels in the image plane :param device: device to store tensors. Defaults to “cpu”. :type device: str, optional

Returns:

(H, W, 2) pixels

Return type:

torch.Tensor

get_pose() → ndarray

returns camera pose in world space :returns: (4, 4) camera pose :rtype: np.ndarray

get_pose_inv() → ndarray

returns camera pose in world space :returns: (4, 4) camera pose :rtype: np.ndarray

get_projection() → ndarray

Return 4x4 camera projection matrix.

get_rays(points_2d_screen: Tensor | None = None, nr_rays_per_pixel: int = 1, jitter_pixels: bool = False, device: str = 'cpu') → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor, Tensor]

returns image rays origins and directions for 2d points on the image plane. If points are not provided, they are sampled from the image plane for every pixel.

Parameters:

  • points_2d_screen (torch.Tensor, float or int, optional) – (N, 2) Values in [0, W-1], [0, H-1]. Default is None.

  • device (str, optional) – device to store tensors. Defaults to “cpu”.

  • jitter_pixels (bool, optional) – Whether to jitter pixels. Only used if points_2d_screen is None. Defaults to False.

Returns:

rays origins (N, 3) rays_d (torch.Tensor): rays directions (N, 3) points_2d_screen (torch.Tensor, float): (N, 2) screen space sampling coordinates

Return type:

rays_o (torch.Tensor)

get_resolution() → Tuple[int, int]

return camera image resolution (width, height)

get_rgb(frame_idx: int = 0) → ndarray

returns, if exists, rgb at frame_idx :param frame_idx: frame index. Defaults to 0. :type frame_idx: int, optional

Returns:

(H, W, 3) rgb frame

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_rgbs() → ndarray

return, if exists, all camera frames :returns: (T, H, W, 3) rgb frames :rtype: np.ndarray

get_rotation() → ndarray

returns camera rotation in world space :returns: (3, 3) camera rotation :rtype: np.ndarray

get_rotation_as_euler() → ndarray

returns camera rotation in world space as euler angles :returns: (3,) camera rotation :rtype: np.ndarray

project_points_3d_world_to_2d_screen(points_3d: ndarray | Tensor, filter_points: bool = True) → Tuple[ndarray | Tensor, ndarray | Tensor]

Projects 3D points to 2D screen space using a camera object.

Parameters:

points_3d (np.ndarray or torch.Tensor) – 3D points in world space of shape (N, 3).

Returns:

2D screen points of shape (N, 2). points_mask (np.ndarray or torch.Tensor): Mask of points outside the image bounds.

Return type:

points_2d_screen (np.ndarray or torch.Tensor)

resize(subsample_factor: float, verbose: bool = False) → None

make frames smaller by scaling them by scale factor (inplace operation) :param subsample_factor: inverse of scale factor :type subsample_factor: float :param verbose: print info :type verbose: bool

set_intrinsics(intrinsics: ndarray) → None

set camera intrinsics

unproject_points_2d_screen_to_3d_world(points_2d_screen: array | Tensor, depth: array | Tensor) → ndarray | Tensor

Unprojects 2D screen points to 3D world space using a camera object.

Parameters:

  • points_2d_screen (np.ndarray or torch.Tensor) – 2D screen points of shape (N, 2).

  • depth (np.ndarray or torch.Tensor) – Depth values of shape (N,).

Returns:

3D points in world space of shape (N, 3).

Return type:

np.ndarray or torch.Tensor
